ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Instructor: Chelsea Elizabeth Judy  Chelsea made a great TF! Her sections were well organized and interactive while also complementing the lectures.It was evident that she worked very hard.
Instructor: Chelsea Elizabeth Judy  Chelsea Judy
Instructor: Chelsea Elizabeth Judy  Chelsea Judy
Instructor: Chelsea Elizabeth Judy  Chelsea Judy
Instructor: Chelsea Elizabeth Judy  Chelsea Judy
Instructor: Chelsea Elizabeth Judy  Chelsea Judy
Instructor: Chelsea Elizabeth Judy  Chelsea Judy
Instructor: Chelsea Elizabeth Judy  Chelsea
Instructor: Chelsea Elizabeth Judy  Chelsea Judy.
Instructor: Chelsea Elizabeth Judy  Chelsea Judy
Instructor: Chelsea Elizabeth Judy  Chelsea Judy.
Instructor: Chelsea Elizabeth Judy  Chelsea Judy

Instructor: Chelsea Elizabeth Judy  Chelsea was an excellent TA, organized and prepared for section. She was great at teaching in section and helped elucidate a lot of concepts that were foggy in class.
Instructor: Chelsea Elizabeth Judy  Chelsea Judy
Instructor: Chelsea Elizabeth Judy  Chelsea Judy
Instructor: Chelsea Elizabeth Judy  Chelsea
Instructor: Chelsea Elizabeth Judy  Chelsea Judy
Instructor: Chelsea Elizabeth Judy  Chelsea Judy
Instructor: Chelsea Elizabeth Judy  Chelsea Judy
Instructor: Chelsea Elizabeth Judy  Chelsea Judy was very helpful in clarifying concepts discussed in class.
Instructor: Chelsea Elizabeth Judy  Chelsea Judy
Instructor: Chelsea Elizabeth Judy  Chelsea Judy
Instructor: Chelsea Elizabeth Judy  Chelsea Judy

Instructor: Chelsea Elizabeth Judy  Chelsea is fantastic. Lecture can be hard to follow and the information a bit over whelming, however she does a great job in breaking it down and making sure we all thoroughly understand

Instructor: Chelsea Elizabeth Judy  Chelsea was very generous with her time inside and outside of class to answer questions and provide helpful feedback. The discussion sessions she set up were extremely useful in preparing us for exams, and the activities she designed were very engaging and thought-provoking.

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Chelsea Elizabeth Judy  Overall, I thought Chelsea was great. Sometimes what she said seemed to conflict with what Prof. Cashore said, but we always got it straightened out.

Instructor: Chelsea Elizabeth Judy  Chelsea developed creative lab sections that reinforced class topics. She also went above and beyond to organize the field trip. Having another TF throughout the entire semester would have been helpful.
Instructor: Chelsea Elizabeth Judy  Chelsea is awesome
Instructor: Chelsea Elizabeth Judy  She cleared up the concepts that we went over in class.

Instructor: Chelsea Elizabeth Judy  Chelsea was great--she could clearly communicate the concepts that we covered in class in a way that was sometimes more understandable and accessible than Professor Cashore's.
Instructor: Chelsea Elizabeth Judy  She was a great teaching assistant. I dont think that his teaching can be improved
Instructor: Chelsea Elizabeth Judy  Always willing to help. Sometimes not so clear when explaining.
Instructor: Chelsea Elizabeth Judy  Chelsea was well-organized, knew the material well, and embraced helping the students. All around an excellent TA.

Instructor: Chelsea Elizabeth Judy  Great discussion leader, but the amount of grading was a lot for one person, so feedback was a bit slow, but that isn't against against Chelesa, just a reflection of the ration of number of students in the class for one TA.

Instructor: Chelsea Elizabeth Judy  The teaching assistant was very knowledgeable, articulate, and put a lot of time into the sessions and helping students. I went to her office hours, which were very helpful, and she was always very response to emails and gave great feedback. I learned a lot from her.
Instructor: Chelsea Elizabeth Judy  I believe she needs to be more confident to be a better teacher. She seems to have a lot of knowledge she could share.
Instructor: Chelsea Elizabeth Judy  Chelsea is a great TA. Great teacher in section, responsive to questions, and provides feedback on written work.

Instructor: Chelsea Elizabeth Judy  She can recap what Ben discusses, but did not really go much beyond that in terms of explaining concepts. Then again, the concepts weren't that complicated and didn't necessarily need more explanation.

Instructor: Chelsea Elizabeth Judy  Chelsea did a really good job of condensing the concepts discussed during lecture. She organized useful exercises to apply what we discussed in class. She was also very open to answering questions.
Instructor: Chelsea Elizabeth Judy  Chelsea was great!

Instructor: Chelsea Elizabeth Judy  Chelsea was knowledgeable and an effective leader of group discussions. Her sections were always well organized and thought-through. However, the feedback we received on our quizzes/policy memo was insufficient, in my opinion. Her feedback didn't further my understanding of the topics.
Instructor: Chelsea Elizabeth Judy  Good at leading section

Instructor: Chelsea Elizabeth Judy  Not organized in the beginning of the course. However, as the semester progressed the sections were very helpful. The lessons talked about in class were applied to real life situations- very helpful!

Instructor: Chelsea Elizabeth Judy  Strengths: -Between her knowledge of the subject matter and ability to better understand Professor Cashore, Chelsea was a good translator of the readings and lectures. -Chelsea was always flexible in the sessions she led. Based on the desires of the class, she would choose to do the planned activity or review topics from class. To work on: -Would it be possible to better help Professor Cashore organize his thoughts and lectures?

Instructor: Chelsea Elizabeth Judy  Chelsea was very good at explaining very complex concepts from class in discussions. She was very creative in using non-environmental examples from current events to illustrate the concepts and this fostered good discussion in section. It was a nice complement to the often abstract and sometimes convoluted class lectures.
Instructor: Chelsea Elizabeth Judy  She did a superb job. She is enthusiastic, organized, thorough, and explains things very clear. I can't think of any ways she can improve!

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Professor Cashore is clearly very brilliant, but sometimes it can be hard to follow what is going on in his head. I don't think he talks too fast, but sometimes he talks without giving proper context, so it leaves students feeling a little confused.

This class was helpful for getting to know the actual framework for developing and designing policies to solve problems, but some of the conceptual material was hard to understand. I really like Prof. Cashore's lectures, but they were a little disorganized. I think a more organized schedule for the class would have been helpful for maybe making the class "flow" a little better. Other than that, I really enjoyed the material we covered and Prof. Cashore's stories and analogies.
Good to know how policy is created.
The professor was very knowledgeable and I learned a lot from his lectures and readings.

This class had a lot of potential--important topics, somewhat interesting readings, and relevant assignments. However, I thought the instructor was rather disorganized during lectures, which made the course disorienting. He tried to fit way too much material into lectures and slides, so by the end, he would be pounding away at the space bar just to get to the end. As a result, it was difficult to understand what lectures were about at the end of classes.

I think this class in theory is incredibly valuable to students interested in advocacy or policy-making, but it was not delivered in an effective way. Ben is a brilliant person who I suspect is great in one-on-one interactions and problem-solving, but his lectures were scattered, way too focused on tangential anecdotes, and lacked any kind of concrete or "actionable" takeaways. Likewise with the reading - I understand the value in having people read political science theory but I also think this class was misrepresented, especially by being labeled a foundations class. It should have political science in the title so people understand what they're going to get into.

The professor might consider re-tailoring the reading selection for the course-- the readings were often very dense and not necessarily the most relevant. Additionally, the evaluative assignments, including the reading quizzes, midterm, final, and policy paper, should be reconsidered. It might benefit the students to focus primarily on the policy paper.

I did not get a lot out of this course. I felt that the classes were very disorganized as the semester progressed. Many times I was not able to follow the professors' lecture. I do not have a background in policy and this class was more geared towards people who do have some background.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Learning how to write the policy memo (useful skill) and hearing from the guest speakers.
The field trip was great. The content was a great primer on environmental policy in practice.
Lectures by Ben
Prof. Cashore's stories.
The professor's lectures and the role playing sections were really valuable to my learning. I enjoyed the speakers and readings and got a lot of experience from writing the policy memo.
I found Wu. et al.'s book to be very clear and informative. I liked the issues it dealt with.

I appreciated hearing Professor Cashore's thought process. He has a unique way of approaching problems that I think everyone should be exposed to. Professor Cashore is not afraid to challenge opinions in a constructive way.
The Wu et al textbook.
The discussion of real examples was very interesting and provided insight into the application of policy.

The material covered in this course initially intrigued me - when Prof Cashore went over it in the first few classes, the readings/lectures seemed relevant and integral to understanding the policy process. The policy memo assignment was a good way to reflect on what we had learned over the course of the semester.
The first half of the class following the Wu. et al. book was a great introduction to the policy process
Content in the first half of the course was most valuable.
Learning to think creatively about designing and implementing effective environmental policies.
Ben is a very dynamic personality and I really appreciated his entertaining side stories he brought into class.
Very thorough, in-depth breakdown of environmental governance and policy on a global scale. Working with an organized framework is very helpful in understanding policy processes

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Perhaps there could be more guest speakers
The syllabus. It kept changing, and it was edited so many times that it was full of errors. It's hard to know what is expected of me when the syllabus is so confusing.
Better organization and focus during the lecture
Found section to be not particularly useful; would've preferred not to do so many simulations and group exercises
If this is a foundations course, there should be more applicable concepts rather than theoretical concepts. It was hard to understand some of the theory without previous policy experience.

I think that this course is too theoretical. I expected to learn more about how environmental policy works in the real world, and not just how it works in the minds of academics. It is good to get some theory, but most of us are going to be practitioners, so a more practical approach would be appreciated. I liked what was covered in the policy primer, because it was a good and simple way frame of how policy is made. However, I didnt find much value in the other readings. Some were good, but most seemed to be the work of academics who have never made policy. It is good to have a theoretical framework to rely on, but often I could not find how the theories connect with reality.
Cover more topics of environmental policy.
A bit disorganized and hectic at times. I think there were approximately 4 or 5 different versions of the syllabus released throughout the semester.
Cover more of the lecture slides in each class. Assign reading that is actually discussed in class. Little motivation for doing some of the extra long readings.
It would be useful to have more guest speakers, since they were really great to hear and helped illuminate some of the concepts we talked about in lecture.
The instructor needs to learn how to effectively teach (i.e. be more organized during lectures) the materials of the course. Otherwise, the course was fine.
More clarity from the Professor. Although this improved very much in the end. Too many readings to do well. More help in "digesting" the readings would be useful.
Lectures sometimes felt a bit scatterbrained and could maybe have benefitted from a clear summary and notes on how to apply the concepts at the end of each lecture.
See question 16

Professor Cashore often talked too fast and didn't explain concepts in detail. Sometimes we ran out of time, which didn't leave room for questions. He might consider slowing down or revising what he discusses.
I think case studies carried out over the course of the semester would be really helpful. Reading direct policy texts might also be an interesting exercise.

The class was disorganized and the readings were dull and dry. Professor Cashore, who is clearly a brilliant researcher, was disorganized and his lectures were all over the place. I thought the assignments were not graded well. This was the class I was most excited about during shopping period, but it ended up being my least favorite class. I don't think I learned very much at all, except for some "policy jargon." The readings focused too much on the history of political theories and were not very practical.
The second half of the course felt a little disorganized.
Second half of the course seemed less structured, lectures became less useful
The schedule changed constantly and wasn't always updated in a timely manner. The strucure o the course was disorganized and confusing at times.
Professor Cashore's stories were entertaining, but often seemed to go off on tangents more than sticking to the topic.
Lecture organization

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: I really enjoyed the simulations in discussion. Maybe if we could be given roles ahead of time, we could better prepare ahead of time and then have more time to do the simulation.
I liked the last sessions of the lab section, where we could play roles to negotiation, learning and other topics taught in the course.
The relationship was well done.
Discussion sections were critical in getting a better understanding of the course lectures.

The relationship between section and lecture was well coordinated. The time devoted to understanding how to write the policy memo was very useful and so were the role playing activities. I appreciated reviewing all of the concepts we learned in lecture in section.
It was effective. Sections were helpful.
I do not think this course needs a section. It did not do anything to enhance my understanding of the subjects.
Discussion section was very helpful for the purposes of understanding the material and the assignments.
Role playing activities worked well; we could also benefit from close readings of the texts during this session
N/A
The sections were good but it would be better if the cases were from a wider variety of topics. There were too many focused in forests
Exercises in section were good illustrations of theoretical concepts learned in class.
The discussion sections were very helpful to apply what was talked about in the class period to real life scenarios. Without the sections I would have been very lost.
It was great being asked to apply in Chelsea's section a lot of the theory we were learning in class.
Very effective. Section was helpful in clarifying and breaking down each lecture

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Great first policy course for environmental scientists.
Perfect fit for my phd.
I'm more of a natural scientist but at least wanted an understanding of policy and politics--this course provided that.
Great foundation for environmental management curriculum and understanding the policy world.

I plan to pursue academic and practitioner-geared classes to become a climate policy analyst. This course gave me a lot of insight into the policy process, specifically related to environmental issues and climate.
This course is very relevant to my overall program as I am interested in environmental policy and governance. This course provided a framework for the field of policy.
A good introduction to policy making

I want to study climate/environmental policy at FES and this class was my first foray into policy studies. I thought it would give me a solid understanding of the policy process and ground me in the realities of policy implementation. I also wanted to learn real-world examples of successful environmental policies.

As someone who has work experience in environmental policy I really liked this course because I could relate the concepts back to the real-world. I had never taken a class before in environmental policy and so this was a great introduction for me and affirmed I wanted to pursue more coursework in this subject.
Environmental studies major, interested in governmental affairs and policy. Therefore, understanding policy processes is critical

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I wanted to study environmental issues from a policy perspective
It was the only interesting course that didn't conflict with all the other courses I signed up for.
I wanted to have a stronger understanding of how policy works in the environmental field.

I wanted to learn more about how policy is made in the real world and how to deal with some of the more important issues in environmental policy like how to convince politicians to care more about the environment, what has been done in the countries that have good environmental policies and how can this be applied to other countries, or what are the stories behind some of the environmental policies in the US.
I want to focus my studies on environmental policy.
See above.
To understand how natural resource policy gets developed.

I took this course to gain a better understanding of the policy process. I have never really taken a public policy class before, but I plan to pursue a career as a policy analyst, so this class was very useful.
I wanted to learn about Environmental Policy and Politics.
I was a political science major and wanted to explore a different scholar's approach from that of my undergraduate studies.
I was hoping to get an introduction to the policy process, which I sort of did and sort of didn't.
I wanted to get a primer on the environmental policy arena to understand how policy is created, implemented, and evaluated.
To gain a broad exposure to policy studies
I majored in Biology in college, so this was my first policy course.
My focus is in policy and this was a good introductory course to theory on policy making
requirement for my degree program

Professor Cashore's pitch at the beginning of the year was convincing. He talked about how many policies are poorly designed or implemented and do therefore not successfully address the issues they were meant to. He mentioned the need to rethink the policy process to better tackle environmental issues.
For my major concentration

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes, I learnt a lot about policy making, analysis and writing policy memos. It met my expectations!
Yes, for the most part. To be honest, I thought we spent too much time on REDD+, I don't think I'll ever work in that field, so it was annoying that we didn't branch out into other areas.
yes
Not entirely. I did learn a lot from writing the memo and from some of the initial classes. However, the second half of the class did not give me any concrete understanding of policy.
No.
No.
Yes.
Yes.
The knowledge I gained from the course exceeded my expectations. The professor was very knowledgeable and the reading selections were very illuminating to understanding the policy process.

Yes. I learned the little that I wanted to learn about policymaking, especially with regard to environmental issues. I'm sure, however, those that are interested in policy probably didn't have their expectations met.

In some ways, it exceeded my expectations. The knowledge I gained allowed me to see environmental policy (or, rather, policy in general) in a different way. I wish I could have had more time to master the concepts taught.

This course was far more theoretical than I thought it would be, and than it was described in its description. The opportunity to apply everything in the policy memo was helpful, but other than that it felt far too abstract for someone like me (interested in on-the-ground policy-making and/or advocacy).

I thought that by taking this course I would have a firm understanding of environmental policy and its application. Unfortunately, we were exposed to a lot of theory without substantial explanation of how it is relevant.
Yes
No as it didn't give me any practical policy skills.
This course did not meet my expectations. I feel like it was very difficult to follow along with many of the lectures. As a result I do not have many key take-aways from this course.
I think I can now better design and analyze policy, but not necessarily do so in a way that is far better than the current paradigm.

The public policy primer, the main textbook, is an extremely good text for practical education. I found it provided a lot of good advice that mid-level managers at any public institution would find helpful.
Very much so

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: We had work groups in sections and those were a great way to interact with the other people in the class who came from different backgrounds.
unique opportunity to go to COP 21
Advantages: Learning from my classmates.
During discussion section, we were split into groups for different exercises. These group assignments were helpful for understanding how policy is actually discussed.
This process was very time consuming, but we were also able to cover more ground as a group than as individuals.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: If you are looking to use the framework of policy to learn about environmental issues, you should take this class!
Know that this course is for people who have never worked in policy; don't expect more from it than what it can offer.
I'd recommend having some policy experience before taking this course. I would also recommend it if you are looking for a more theoretical understanding of environmental policy.
Do the readings.
Worthwhile, with some learning that goes into which readings are worth doing.
Make sure to attend the sections that involved role playing different policy processes. They were really informative.
Just be aware that this is a political science course. There is very little actual discussion of on-the-ground "politics and practice" aside from a few random anecdotes delivered in lecture.

Focus on the most relevant readings, because they can get overwhelming. Clarify questions about the fundamentals early because everything ends up building upon previous material throughout the semester.

This class is very theoretical and dry. If a student is interested in learning about natural resource management from a purely theoretical perspective, I would recommend this course. If he/she wants to learn about the practical aspects of environmental policy, I wouldn't recommend it.
If you are looking for clear easy-to-follow structure, look somewhere else. If you learn well through stories, tangents, and creative thinking, this may be the course for you.

If you have had prior public policy experience, I think this course will definitely help you further understand the underlying complexities of power dynamics that exist in any institution. It is extremely helpful to draw back on your own experiences to reinforce some of the more abstract aspects of this course. However, for anyone still interested in gaining insight into policy at just a broader level I think it is still very useful. Definitely read the text, it is extremely easy and practical and I predict it will actually be a reference guide for me in the future.
Keep up with the readings, and be sure to get as much as you can possible out of section. Meet with your TA and Professor Cashore, they are very helpful on a face-to-face level
